newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: SingTel down, dampened by India pull out.
newsitem.headline: SingTel down, dampened by India pull out.

text.p: The share price of Singapore Telecommunications Ltd (SingTel) fell Singapore $0.06 to S$3.22 on Monday, dampened by reports it was pulling out of a bid for India's Tamil Nadu cellular phone license, analysts said.
Volume was over a million shares at 0710 GMT.

SingTel chief executive officer Lee Hsien Yang was quoted in Singapore media as saying SingTel had decided to quit the consortium which bid for the license as it did not believe the project would be viable if they had to top up their bid.
"People are disappointed with (SingTel's) regional push," an analyst with a Singapore brokerage house said.

SingTel, jointly with HCL Ltd and the Hinduja group, was the second highest bidder in a tender for two licenses in the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu. SingTel's consortium submitted a bid of 5.41 billion rupees in 1995. The highest bidder was US West-BPL at 8.36 billion rupees.
The tender requires the second highest bidder to match the top bid in order to secure the second license.

SingTel's Lee was quoted as saying: "Basically, we are not prepared to participate, though I think our partners are keen and are looking to other parties who may be interested to take out our shares." -- Singapore newsroom (65 8703080)
